articles.headline: With Retirement Savings, It’s a Sprint to the Finish
articles.snippet: You can save all your life, but those last years before you retire will determine the result.
articles.abstract: You can save all your life, but those last years before you retire will determine the result.
articles.lead_paragraph: What would you do if your financial planner prescribed the following advice? Save and invest diligently for 30 years, then cross your fingers and pray your investments will double over the last decade before you retire.

articles.headline: Obama Sends Pro-Business Signal With Adviser Choice
articles.snippet: The selection of Jeffrey R. Immelt, the G.E. chief, for economic council adviser signals a shift in strategy for the White House.
articles.abstract: The selection of Jeffrey R. Immelt, the G.E. chief, for economic council adviser signals a shift in strategy for the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. — President Obama, sending another strong signal that he intends to make the White House more business-friendly, named a high-profile corporate executive on Friday as his chief outside economic adviser, continuing his efforts to show more focus on job creation and reclaim the political center.

articles.headline: You Think Houses Are a Slow Sell? Try a Yacht
articles.snippet: The market for yachts is still depressed long after the recession has ended, discouraging would-be buyers and leaving owners unable to sell.
articles.abstract: The market for yachts is still depressed long after the recession has ended, discouraging would-be buyers and leaving owners unable to sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is tougher than having one sleek mega-yacht for sale in a glutted market? The answer, for the moment at least, is having two mega-yachts on the market.

articles.headline: Shamed Into Altering a Mortgage
articles.snippet: The bank altered a home loan for a 73-year-old Queens woman, but not until the homeowner’s predicament received some publicity.
articles.abstract: The bank altered a home loan for a 73-year-old Queens woman, but not until the homeowner’s predicament received some publicity.
articles.lead_paragraph: In physics, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle states that the process of observing subatomic particles affects their behavior. We have a similar principle in journalism: the process of reporting a story can sometimes affect the behavior of those being reported on. Last Wednesday, the Heisenberg Journalism Principle was on full display in a courtroom at the Queens County Courthouse, in New York.

articles.headline: Across Country, Lawmakers Push Abortion Curbs
articles.snippet: Conservative lawmakers in dozens of states, energized by midterm electoral gains, are working aggressively to limit abortions.
articles.abstract: Conservative lawmakers in dozens of states, energized by midterm electoral gains, are working aggressively to limit abortions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newly energized by their success in November’s midterm elections, conservative legislators in dozens of states are mounting aggressive campaigns to limit abortions.

articles.headline: A Creator Prepares to Take the Reins at Google
articles.snippet: Larry Page’s move to chief executive will test his skills at handling the daily grind of running a business.
articles.abstract: Larry Page’s move to chief executive will test his skills at handling the daily grind of running a business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Things that get Larry Page excited: tossing around programming lingo with engineers, picking the brains of scientists and championing ideas that belong in science-fiction novels, like cars that drive themselves.

articles.headline: In Tucson, Solace From Relatives of Past Killers
articles.snippet: The parents of Jared L. Loughner are being approached by the kin of those who have also gone on killing sprees.
articles.abstract: The parents of Jared L. Loughner are being approached by the kin of those who have also gone on killing sprees.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON  Few visitors make their way past the cactus garden and into the dark ranch-style home where Randy and Amy Loughner have spent much time grieving alone. The rampage in which their troubled 22-year-old son is accused opened a fault line between them and the rest of this recovering city.

articles.headline: Slap to a Man’s Pride Set Off Tumult in Tunisia
articles.snippet: Mohamed Bouazizi, the fruit vendor who died after setting himself on fire, has become a symbol of defiance in Tunisia.
articles.abstract: Mohamed Bouazizi, the fruit vendor who died after setting himself on fire, has become a symbol of defiance in Tunisia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIDI BOUZID, Tunisia — Mohamed Bouazizi spent his whole life on a dusty, narrow street here, in a tiny, three-room house with a concrete patio where his mother hung the laundry and the red chilis to dry. By the time Mr. Bouazizi was 26, his work as a fruit vendor had earned him just enough money to feed his mother, uncle and five brothers and sisters at home. He dreamed about owning a van.

articles.headline: Maybe Japan Was Just a Warm-Up
articles.snippet: The trade tensions with China sometimes seem like a rerun of the 1980s rivalry with Japan. But can Washington use its old strategies?
articles.abstract: The trade tensions with China sometimes seem like a rerun of the 1980s rivalry with Japan. But can Washington use its old strategies?
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the 1980s, the United States faced an unnerving challenge from a rising economic powerhouse and export dynamo. It was an impressive challenger, to be sure, but one that often bent rules of global competition unfairly to its advantage by handing out financial subsidies to domestic companies, discriminating against foreign suppliers in government contracts, pilfering Western technology and keeping its currency cheap.

articles.headline: Pay Doubles for Bosses at Viacom
articles.snippet: The awards raised questions among compensation experts.
articles.abstract: The awards raised questions among compensation experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Viacom presents: Big Payday II  the sequel.

articles.headline: High Price for India’s Information Law
articles.snippet: Activists have been harassed, beaten and killed when they have used a right-to-know law to make inquiries.
articles.abstract: Activists have been harassed, beaten and killed when they have used a right-to-know law to make inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: KODINAR, India  Amit Jethwa had just left his lawyer’s office after discussing a lawsuit he had filed to stop an illicit limestone quarry with ties to powerful local politicians. That is when the assassins struck, speeding out of the darkness on a roaring motorbike, pistols blazing. He died on the spot, blood pouring from his mouth and nose. He was 38.

articles.headline: Static on the Citadel Radio Dial
articles.snippet: The nation’s third-largest broadcaster, which emerged from bankruptcy last June, baffled and angered big shareholders when it refused two offers from a rival, Cumulus Media.
articles.abstract: The nation’s third-largest broadcaster, which emerged from bankruptcy last June, baffled and angered big shareholders when it refused two offers from a rival, Cumulus Media.
articles.lead_paragraph: EXECUTIVES who run public companies, and the directors who oversee them, are supposed to operate with the shareholders’ best interests at heart. If a capitalist society like ours is to function, that has to be a bedrock principle.

articles.headline: Quarterback for a Team of 1,900
articles.snippet: DeMaurice Smith, hard-charging director of the N.F.L. players’ union, has sought the advice of other labor leaders in its contract dispute with owners.
articles.abstract: DeMaurice Smith, hard-charging director of the N.F.L. players’ union, has sought the advice of other labor leaders in its contract dispute with owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: “WE are at war!” DeMaurice Smith yelled.

articles.headline: Former Spy With Agenda Operates a Private C.I.A.
articles.snippet: A network of spies run by Duane R. Clarridge shows how private citizens can exploit the chaos of rivalries inside the government to carry out their agenda.
articles.abstract: A network of spies run by Duane R. Clarridge shows how private citizens can exploit the chaos of rivalries inside the government to carry out their agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Duane R. Clarridge parted company with the Central Intelligence Agency more than two decades ago, but from poolside at his home near San Diego, he still runs a network of spies.

articles.headline: Obama to Press Centrist Agenda in His Address
articles.snippet: President Obama will strike a theme of national unity and renewal in his State of the Union address Tuesday as he stresses the need for both government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit.
articles.abstract: President Obama will strike a theme of national unity and renewal in his State of the Union address Tuesday as he stresses the need for both government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama will outline an agenda for “winning the future” in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night, striking a theme of national unity and renewal as he stresses the need for government spending in key areas and an attack on the budget deficit.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: The Thorny Path to a National Black Museum
articles.snippet: Addressing a topic as fraught as race would be challenging anywhere, but it is particularly tricky within the Smithsonian.
articles.abstract: Addressing a topic as fraught as race would be challenging anywhere, but it is particularly tricky within the Smithsonian.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, when Lonnie G. Bunch III had his first job at the Smithsonian’s National Air and Space Museum, veterans of the Tuskegee Airmen, the all-black squadron, accused the museum of playing down their contributions during World War II. In response, the museum asked some of the African-Americans on staff to allow their faces to be used on mannequins, increasing the “black presence” in its exhibits.

articles.headline: China Grooming Deft Politician as Next Leader
articles.snippet: Following a succession plan laid out years ago, President Hu Jintao will pass the baton to his presumed successor, Xi Jinping, now China’s vice president.
articles.abstract: Following a succession plan laid out years ago, President Hu Jintao will pass the baton to his presumed successor, Xi Jinping, now China’s vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  President Hu Jintao of China returned home this weekend after a trip intended to repair relations with the United States. But the next time the White House marches out the honor guard and polishes the crystal for a Chinese leader, it is unlikely to be for Mr. Hu.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: MTV’s Naked Calculation Gone Bad
articles.snippet: MTV clearly erred when it decided that conjuring a show out of semi-nude teenagers would be harmless fun.
articles.abstract: MTV clearly erred when it decided that conjuring a show out of semi-nude teenagers would be harmless fun.
articles.lead_paragraph: What if one day you went to work and there was a meeting to discuss whether the project you were working on crossed the line into child pornography? You’d probably think you had ended up in the wrong room.

articles.headline: The Understudy Takes the Stage at Apple
articles.snippet: When Timothy D. Cook is on his own, he will have to compensate for the absence of Steven P. Jobs.
articles.abstract: When Timothy D. Cook is on his own, he will have to compensate for the absence of Steven P. Jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: On an 18-hour flight from California to Singapore a few years ago, Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief operating officer, had little time for small talk with a colleague. Glued to his business class seat, Mr. Cook had his nose in spreadsheets, preparing for a thorough review of Apple’s Asian operations.

articles.headline: Despite Distinctions, Los Angeles Times Loses Standing at Home
articles.snippet: The paper maintains 13 foreign bureaus and is a front-runner for a Pulitzer Prize this year, but its weekday circulation has been nearly halved since 2000.
articles.abstract: The paper maintains 13 foreign bureaus and is a front-runner for a Pulitzer Prize this year, but its weekday circulation has been nearly halved since 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Big-city newspapers all across the country have suffered one indignity after another in the last few years. But few of them have been as hard hit — or gotten as much grief for it — as The Los Angeles Times.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Is Studying the Risk of Electroshock Devices
articles.snippet: A federal study renews the debate over electroshock therapy, which is used to treat 100,000 Americans for depression and other illnesses.
articles.abstract: A federal study renews the debate over electroshock therapy, which is used to treat 100,000 Americans for depression and other illnesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators are weighing whether to downgrade the risk classification of electroshock devices, reinforcing what many psychiatrists consider a deepening acceptance of electroshock in modern therapy.

articles.headline: Art Exhibit Stirs Up the Ghosts of Zimbabwe’s Past
articles.snippet: The government’s efforts to bury history have instead provoked memories of the Gukurahundi, Zimbabwe’s name for the slaying and torture of thousands of civilians.
articles.abstract: The government’s efforts to bury history have instead provoked memories of the Gukurahundi, Zimbabwe’s name for the slaying and torture of thousands of civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe  The exhibit at the National Gallery is now a crime scene, the artwork banned and the artist charged with insulting President Robert Mugabe. The picture windows that showcased graphic depictions of atrocities committed in the early years of Mr. Mugabe’s 30-year-long rule are now papered over with the yellowing pages of a state-controlled newspaper.

articles.headline: Olbermann Split Came After Years of Tension
articles.snippet: Underlying the decision to part ways with Keith Olbermann were years of behind-the-scenes conflicts.
articles.abstract: Underlying the decision to part ways with Keith Olbermann were years of behind-the-scenes conflicts.
articles.lead_paragraph: MSNBC never had any doubt about what it was getting when it made Keith Olbermann the face of the network in 2003: a highly talented broadcaster, a distinctive and outspoken voice and a mercurial personality with a track record of attacking his superiors and making early exits.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: A Miami Beach Event Space. Parking Space, Too.
articles.snippet: A strange marriage of high-end architecture and car storage, a $65 million parking garage is drawing crowds.
articles.abstract: A strange marriage of high-end architecture and car storage, a $65 million parking garage is drawing crowds.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH, Fla.  For her wedding over the weekend, Nina Johnson had worked through a predictable checklist of locations in town: hotel ballrooms, restaurant halls and catering outfits.

articles.headline: State of Union Near, G.O.P. Draws Line on Spending
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans are trying to recapture the debate over the country’s economic recovery.
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans are trying to recapture the debate over the country’s economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans, seeking to recapture the debate over the country’s economic recovery in advance of President Obama’s State of the Union address, warned Sunday that they would oppose any new spending initiatives and press ahead with their plans for budget cuts in every realm of government, including the military.

articles.headline: Mortgage Giants Leave Legal Bills to the Taxpayers
articles.snippet: Since the government took over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, taxpayers have spent more than $160 million defending their former top executives in fraud lawsuits.
articles.abstract: Since the government took over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, taxpayers have spent more than $160 million defending their former top executives in fraud lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the government took over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, taxpayers have spent more than $160 million defending the mortgage finance companies and their former top executives in civil lawsuits accusing them of fraud. The cost was a closely guarded secret until last week, when the companies and their regulator produced an accounting at the request of Congress.

articles.headline: Deadly Blast Comes at Sensitive Time for Russia
articles.snippet: A suicide bomb attack that killed dozens of people at Moscow’s busiest airport injected new pain into a country already split along ethnic lines.
articles.abstract: A suicide bomb attack that killed dozens of people at Moscow’s busiest airport injected new pain into a country already split along ethnic lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  A suicide bomber attacked Moscow’s busiest airport on Monday, killing dozens of people and injecting new pain into a country already split along ethnic lines.
